num_tested_probands: The study reports on two Iranian families affected by autosomal recessive intellectual disability (ARID). The proband in the first family was homozygous for a missense mutation in the SARS gene, while the second family had a compound heterozygous genotype of the WARS2 gene.
The number of probands tested is 8, as indicated in the table.
The study tested 5 individuals from two families with a history of intellectual disability and other neurological symptoms.
The number of probands tested is mentioned in the text as 'DNA was extracted from peripheral blood of the patients, two healthy siblings and their parents, using standard procedures.'
The number of probands tested is 11, as stated in Figure 3.
The study reports that genetic testing was performed on 15 individual probands.
num_positive_het_probands: No probands were reported to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
No proband was found to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
Out of these, 2 individuals were found to be heterozygous for the mutation.
Three probands were heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
No proband was found to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
Four probands are heterozygous for a pathogenic variant, as mentioned in the discussion section.
No proband was found to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
positive_phenotypes: The study reports on two Iranian families affected by autosomal recessive intellectual disability (ARID). The proband in the first family had moderate ID, microcephaly, ataxia, speech impairment, and aggressive behavior. The second family also had ARID with similar accompanying features.
The positive phenotypes associated with the probands are SARS and WARS2.
The affected individuals presented with a range of symptoms including moderate ID, athetosis, aggressive behavior, speech impairment, muscular weakness, and ataxia.
None of the positive probands had any clinical phenotypes mentioned in the report.
The positive proband phenotypes include moderate ID, speech impairment, seizures, ataxia, and muscular weakness, which are consistent with previous reports on ARSs and tRNA-related disorders.
The positive probands exhibited autosomal recessive intellectual disability, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 2N (CMT2N), and Alpers syndrome.
num_compound_or_double_hets: No compound or double heterozygotes were reported.
There were no compound or double heterozygotes reported in the study.

One compound heterozygous genotype was found in affected individuals, consisting of a deleterious frame-shift mutation and a missense change (p.Trp13Gly) in the mitochondrial tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase encoding WARS2.
One compound heterozygote was identified in the study.

quote_snippets.num_positive_het_probands: Four probands are heterozygous for a pathogenic variant, as mentioned in the discussion section.
quote_snippets.text: In this report, we describe putatively ID causing mutations in SARS and WARS2 in families with closely overlapping additional clinical features including moderate ID, speech impairment, seizures, ataxia, and muscular weakness.

quote_snippets.positive_phenotypes: The positive proband phenotypes include moderate ID, speech impairment, seizures, ataxia, and muscular weakness, which are consistent with previous reports on ARSs and tRNA-related disorders.
quote_snippets.text: The occurrence of ataxia is consistent with previous reports that implicate ARSs in the etiology of this particular feature (see e.g. (Lee et al., 2006)). Moreover, muscular weakness was repeatedly observed in the context of tRNA-related disorders in general or ARS-related conditions in particular, for example, Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease (MIM# 607731) and others (see e.g. (Abbott, Francklyn, & Robey-Bond, 2014; Bansagi et al., 2015; Irobi, De Jonghe, & Timmerman, 2004; McLaughlin et al., 2012), which also supports our conclusion that the phenotype in our families is caused by the DNA-alterations we report here.

quote_snippets.text: In the second family, whole genome sequencing revealed a compound heterozygous genotype in affected individuals, consisting of a deleterious frame-shift mutation and a missense change (p.Trp13Gly) in the mitochondrial tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase encoding WARS2.
